title: Modeling with Differential Eq Separation Variables

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.At an aquarium, a tank is kept full of water. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in minutes, the water in the tank contains no salt. For time <math alttext="t greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, water containing salt flows into the tank at a constant rate and mixes with the water in the tank. The mixed water leaves the tank through an overflow drain at the same constant rate. The number of pounds of salt in the water in the tank at time <math alttext="t greater than or equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is modeled by the function <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></math>, which satisfies the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of S with respect to t, equals negative one sixth times, open parenthesis, S minus 36, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> with initial condition <math alttext="S of 0, equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>S</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>.(a) Is the amount of salt in the water in the tank changing more rapidly when the water contains <math alttext="6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn></math> pounds of salt or when the water contains <math alttext="30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>30</mn></math> pounds of salt? Explain your reasoning.

Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.At an aquarium, a tank is kept full of water. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in minutes, the water in the tank contains no salt. For time <math alttext="t greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, water containing salt flows into the tank at a constant rate and mixes with the water in the tank. The mixed water leaves the tank through an overflow drain at the same constant rate. The number of pounds of salt in the water in the tank at time <math alttext="t greater than or equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is modeled by the function <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></math>, which satisfies the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of S with respect to t, equals negative one sixth times, open parenthesis, S minus 36, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> with initial condition <math alttext="S of 0, equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>S</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>.(a) Is the amount of salt in the water in the tank changing more rapidly when the water contains <math alttext="6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn></math> pounds of salt or when the water contains <math alttext="30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>30</mn></math> pounds of salt? Explain your reasoning.

(b) Write an expression for <math alttext="the second derivative of S, with respect to t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></math> in terms of <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>S</mi></math>. Find the value of <math alttext="the second derivative of S, with respect to t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></math> at the instant when there are <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> pounds of salt in the water in the tank. Using correct units, interpret this value in the context of the problem.

(c) Use separation of variables to find <math alttext="y equals, S of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>S</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>, the particular solution to the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of S with respect to t, equals negative one sixth times, open parenthesis, S minus 36, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> with initial condition <math alttext="S of 0, equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 4.3: Rates of Change in Applied Contexts Other Than Motion

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
